train_details.author: O. Henry
train_details.title: The Gift of the Magi
train_details.prediction:
The snow fell thick and silent outside, a fitting backdrop to the quiet desperation clinging to Della and Jim Young’s shabby little couch. It was Christmas Eve, and the air, thick with the scent of pine and something vaguely resembling regret, held a single, stark truth: one dollar and eighty-seven cents. That’s all they had. Mr. James Dillingham Young, a man of considerable girth and even more considerable anxieties, would be utterly bewildered.

Della, bless her heart, was already at it, a frantic, almost balletic dance with the pawn shop owner. Jim, meanwhile, was meticulously sketching the flat – a depressing tableau of peeling wallpaper and a threadbare rug – a futile attempt to capture the essence of their predicament. He’d always been a practical man, Jim, but even he couldn’t deny the tightening knot in his stomach.

“I’ll sell my hair,” Della declared, her voice a brittle whisper. “I’ll sell it all!” Jim chuckled, a dry, humorless sound. He knew, of course, that she was referring to her magnificent, cascading tresses – the very pride of her being. The irony, a particularly sharp and bitter one, hung heavy in the air. It was a Christmas dilemma of the most exquisite, and utterly devastating, kind.
train_details.reference: One dollar and eighty-seven cents. That was all. And sixty cents of it was in pennies. Pennies saved one and two at a time by bulldozing the grocer and the vegetable man and the butcher until one's cheeks burned with the silent imputation of parsimony that such close dealing implied. Three times Della counted it. One dollar and eighty-seven cents. And the next day would be Christmas. There was clearly nothing to do but flop down on the shabby little couch and howl. So Della did it. Which instigates the moral reflection that life is made up of sobs, sniffles, and smiles, with sniffles predominating. While the mistress of the home is gradually subsiding from the first stage to the second, take a look at the home. A furnished flat at $8 per week. It did not exactly beggar description, but it certainly had that word on the look-out for the mendicancy squad. In the vestibule below was a letter-box into which no letter would go, and an electric button from which no mortal finger could coax a ring. Also appertaining thereunto was a card bearing the name "Mr. James Dillingham Young." The "Dillingham" had been flung to the breeze during a former period of prosperity when its possessor was being paid $30 per week.

train_details.author: Emily Dickinson
train_details.title: Because I could not stop for Death
train_details.feedback: Score=0.51 | Words=0 (target 140-170) | Motifs=2/3 | Overlap=0.55 | Missing motifs: carriage held but just ourselves
train_details.prediction:
The carriage waits, a burden just for two,
And we, within its hold, begin our way,
Past schoolyard walls, a faded, distant hue,
Toward the setting sun’s departing ray.

The Fields of Gazing Grain stretch wide and deep,
A golden ocean, silent, still, and slow,
Where shadows lengthen, secrets softly sleep,
And weary breezes whisper, to and fro.

The horses’ heads, with patient, solemn grace,
Do pull the wheels along the dusty track,
A measured pace, in this forsaken place,
No turning back, no turning, looking back.

The grave-house looms, a somber, shadowed sign,
A final resting place, serene and white,
Where earthly joys and sorrows intertwine,
And darkness claims the fading, failing light.

A quiet comfort settles on the air,
A shared observance, calm and deeply true,
As Death, our driver, guides us unaware,
Toward the realms beyond, forever new.
train_details.reference: Because I could not stop for Death -- He kindly stopped for me -- The Carriage held but just Ourselves -- And Immortality. We slowly drove -- He knew no haste And I had put away My labor and my leisure too, For His Civility -- We passed the School, where Children strove At Recess -- in the Ring -- We passed the Fields of Gazing Grain -- We passed the Setting Sun -- Or rather -- He passed Us -- The Dews drew quivering and Chill -- For only Gossamer, my Gown -- My Tippet -- only Tulle -- We paused before a House that seemed A Swelling of the Ground -- The Roof was scarcely visible -- The Cornice -- in the Ground -- Since then -- 'tis Centuries -- and yet Feels shorter than the Day I first surmised the Horses' Heads Were toward Eternity --

train_details.author: Walt Whitman
train_details.title: O Captain! My Captain!
train_details.prediction:
The harbor sighs, a welcome, golden hue,
And bells proclaim the voyage safely done,
A joyous sound, a triumph shining through,
Yet shadows cling beneath the setting sun.
The fearful trip is done, the tempest past,
But memory’s grip holds fast, a bitter plea,
For dear father lost, a love that could not last,
Now fallen cold and dead, eternally.

The rigging strains, a testament to might,
To weathered spars and sails that kissed the foam,
Returning home, a beacon burning bright,
While grief’s dark tide still claims its weary home.
The cheers ascend, a chorus bold and free,
Yet in my heart, a mournful echo rings,
A silent sorrow, deep for all to see,
Of shattered hopes and broken, grieving things.

Let trumpets blare, let revelry unfold,
A nation’s pride in victory displayed,
But in this space, a story to be told,
Of loss and longing, silently conveyed.
The sea remembers, vast and ever deep,
The captain’s soul, now resting in the blue,
And in my heart, a solemn vigil keep,
For him, my dear father, lost and true.
train_details.reference: O Captain! My Captain! by Walt Whitman O Captain! my Captain! our fearful trip is done, The ship has weather'd every rack, the prize we sought is won, The port is near, the bells I hear, the people all exulting, While follow eyes the steady keel, the vessel grim and daring; But O heart! heart! heart! O the bleeding drops of red, Where on the deck my Captain lies, Fallen cold and dead. O Captain! my Captain! rise up and hear the bells; Rise up--for you the flag is flung--for you the bugle trills, For you bouquets and ribbon'd wreaths--for you the shores a-crowding, For you they call, the swaying mass, their eager faces turning; Here Captain! dear father! This arm beneath your head! It is some dream that on the deck, You've fallen cold and dead. My Captain does not answer, his lips are pale and still, My father does not feel my arm, he has no pulse nor will, The ship is anchor'd safe and sound, its voyage closed and done, From fearful trip the victor ship comes in with object won; Exult O shores, and ring O bells! But I with mournful tread, Walk the deck my Captain lies, Fallen cold and dead.

train_details.author: F Scott Fitzgerald
train_details.title: The Great Gatsby
train_details.prediction: My father, a man who’d spent his life measuring the distance between things – the distance between a handshake and a lie, between a promise and its fulfillment – used to say, “Reserve all judgments, Nick. It’s a fool’s errand, really, but a necessary one.” He wasn’t referring, of course, to the glittering throng that’s begun to populate West Egg. There’s old money, naturally, and then there’s this… new wealth, a frantic, almost desperate attempt to prove itself worthy of the first. I’ve been observing them, these men – wild, unknown men with eyes that hold a disconcerting stillness, and women who seem perpetually poised on the edge of a laugh or a tear. They throw lavish parties, fueled by bootleg liquor and a desperate need for validation. I saw Gatsby, for instance, last night, holding court with a collection of faces I didn’t recognize, each radiating a carefully constructed air of importance. There’s a current of secret grief running beneath the champagne bubbles, a quiet acknowledgement that all this… this performance… is built on something fragile. It’s a peculiar breed, this generation, and I find myself both fascinated and profoundly uneasy.
train_details.reference: In my younger and more vulnerable years my father gave me some advice that I've been turning over in my mind ever since. "Whenever you feel like criticizing anyone," he told me, "just remember that all the people in this world haven't had the advantages that you've had." He didn't say any more, but we've always been unusually communicative in a reserved way, and I understood that he meant a great deal more than that. In consequence, I'm inclined to reserve all judgements, a habit that has opened up many curious natures to me and also made me the victim of not a few veteran bores. The abnormal mind is quick to detect and attach itself to this quality when it appears in a normal person, and so it came about that in college I was unjustly accused of being a politician, because I was privy to the secret griefs of wild, unknown men. Most of the confidences were unsought--frequently I have feigned sleep, preoccupation, or a hostile levity when I realized by some unmistakable sign that an intimate revelation was quivering on the horizon; for the intimate revelations of young men, or at least the terms in which they express them, are usually plagiaristic and marred by obvious suppressions.

train_details.author: Christina Rossetti
train_details.title: In the Bleak Midwinter
train_details.feedback: Score=0.50 | Words=0 (target 160-190) | Motifs=2/3 | Overlap=0.51 | Missing motifs: snow on snow
train_details.prediction:
The snow falls soft, on snow so deep,
A silent hush, where shadows sleep.
The stars above, a distant gleam,
Reflecting in a winter dream.

The stable small, a humble place,
Where love descended, grace and grace.
A manger waits, a simple plea,
“Stable-place sufficed, for you and me.”

An angel’s song, a whispered plea,
Of peace and joy, eternally.
The frosted fields, a silver hue,
A promise kept, forever true.

Let gentle light begin to flow,
A warmth within, a tender glow.
Like snowflakes drifting, soft and slow,
Give my heart, let kindness grow.

No jewels or gold, no lavish art,
But love’s true gift, a beating heart.
A quiet grace, a humble sign,
Of God’s great love, divinely thine.
train_details.reference: In the bleak midwinter Frosty wind made moan; Earth stood hard as iron, Water like a stone; Snow had fallen, snow on snow, Snow on snow, In the bleak midwinter, Long ago. Our God, Heaven cannot hold Him, Nor earth sustain; Heaven and earth shall flee away When He comes to reign. In the bleak midwinter A stable-place sufficed The Lord God Almighty, Jesus Christ. Enough for Him, whom cherubim Worship night and day, A breastful of milk And a mangerful of hay; Enough for Him, whom angels Fall down before, The ox and ass and camel Which adore. Angels and archangels May have gathered there, Cherubim and seraphim Thronged the air; But only His mother In her maiden bliss Worshipped the Beloved With a kiss. What can I give Him, Poor as I am? If I were a shepherd I would bring a lamb; If I were a Wise Man I would do my part; Yet what I can I give Him, Give my heart.

train_details.author: Guy de Maupassant
train_details.title: The Necklace
train_details.prediction:
The Ministry of Public Instruction seemed a lifetime away, a bureaucratic abstraction compared to the suffocating reality of the apartment. It wasn’t simply the worn-out chairs, though they certainly contributed to the pervasive sense of decay, but the sheer, unrelenting drabness of it all. Mathilde’s dreams, vibrant and insistent, were a stark contrast – glittering salons, filled with the murmur of polite conversation and the clinking of crystal. She’d imagine herself, draped in silk, a jewel amongst the assembled, listening to witty repartee, a fleeting escape from the endless, grey days.

The error of destiny, she often thought, wasn’t simply her birth into a clerk’s household, but the cruel insistence of her own desires. Each chipped teacup, each threadbare rug, was a tiny, agonizing reminder of her confinement. She’d picture the elaborate gowns, the perfumed air, the effortless grace of the women she observed in her fantasies. It was a hunger, a desperate craving for beauty, for recognition, for a life that felt, even momentarily, complete. The contrast between her imagined world and her present existence was a constant, sharp ache.
train_details.reference: She was one of those pretty and charming girls, born, as if through an error of destiny, into a family of clerks. She had no dowry, no hopes, no means of being known, understood, loved, married by a man either rich or distinguished; and she let herself be married to a little clerk at the Ministry of Public Instruction. She dressed plainly because she could not dress well; but she was as unhappy as if she had really fallen from a higher station, since with women there is neither caste nor rank: and beauty, grace and charm act instead of family and birth. Natural ingenuity, instinct for what is elegant, a supple mind are their sole hierarchy, and make girls of the people the equals of the grand ladies. She suffered incessantly, feeling herself born for all the delicacies and all the luxuries. She suffered from the poverty of her dwelling, from the wretched look of the walls, from the worn-out chairs, from the ugliness of the curtains. All those things of which another woman of her rank would even not have been aware tormented her and made her angry.

train_details.author: Edgar Allan Poe
train_details.title: The Tell-Tale Heart
train_details.feedback: Score=0.40 | Words=0 (target 190-210) | Motifs=2/3 | Overlap=0.53 | Missing motifs: very, very dreadfully
train_details.prediction:
Listen… please. Don’t think I’m mad. It’s simply… heightened. The light, you see? It’s *very, very* intense. And him. That old man. He sits there, doesn’t he? Just… sitting. And his eye. That pale blue eye. It’s watching. Always watching. It’s not a gaze, not really. More like a… a pressure. A weight. 

I tell you, I’m perfectly rational. I observe. I analyze. But the sounds… the sounds are overwhelming. A scratching, a clicking, a low hum that vibrates in my teeth. It’s coming from *his* eye, I’m certain. It’s pulling.  The blood ran cold just now, I swear it. Just a flicker, a shadow.  

Don’t you see? It’s not madness. It’s… clarity. A terrible, piercing clarity.  He doesn’t *look* at me, not truly. He sees *through* me.  That pale blue eye… it’s a window. A window into something… dreadful.  I’m trying to hold onto my sanity, I am!  But it’s slipping.  Very, very slipping.  Just… listen to the hum. Do you hear it?
train_details.reference: True! -- nervous -- very, very dreadfully nervous I had been and am; but why will you say that I am mad? The disease had sharpened my senses -- not destroyed -- not dulled them. Above all was the sense of hearing acute. I heard all things in the heaven and in the earth. I heard many things in hell. How, then, am I mad? Hearken! and observe how healthily -- how calmly I can tell you the whole story. It is impossible to say how first the idea entered my brain; but once conceived, it haunted me day and night. Object there was none. Passion there was none. I loved the old man. He had never wronged me. He had never given me insult. For his gold I had no desire. I think it was his eye! yes, it was this! One of his eyes resembled that of a vulture -- a pale blue eye, with a film over it. Whenever it fell upon me, my blood ran cold; and so by degrees -- very gradually -- I made up my mind to take the life of the old man, and thus rid myself of the eye forever.

train_details.author: Ernest Hemingway
train_details.title: A Farewell To Arms
train_details.feedback: Score=0.41 | Words=0 (target 190-220) | Motifs=2/3 | Overlap=0.55 | Missing motifs: dust rising
train_details.prediction:
The late summer heat clung to the Arno, thick and insistent. Dust rose in swirling columns from the newly turned fields, a perpetual haze blurring the edges of San Martino. Motor-tractors, idle now, sat slumped in the piazza, their engines silent. It had been like this for days. The rain hadn’t come, hadn’t come at all. Just this dust, this heat, this slow, suffocating stillness.

Another column passed this morning, grey figures moving with a mechanical precision. They moved through the village as they moved through every village, a ripple in the landscape. The men were young, mostly, and their faces were grim. I watched them go, recording details – the mud on their boots, the way they adjusted their helmets.

The river flowed on, indifferent. It always flowed on. The sun beat down, relentless. More dust. More heat. The air tasted of dry earth and something else, something metallic and distant. It was a familiar taste. It had been like this before, and it would be like this again. The rain hadn’t come, hadn’t come at all.
train_details.reference: In the late summer of that year we lived in a house in a village that looked across the river and the plain to the mountains. In the bed of the river there were pebbles and boulders, dry and white in the sun, and the water was clear and swiftly moving and blue in the channels. Troops went by the house and down the road and the dust they raised powdered the leaves of the trees. The trunks of the trees too were dusty and the leaves fell early that year and we saw the troops marching along the road and the dust rising and leaves, stirred by the breeze, falling and the soldiers marching and afterward the road bare and white except for the leaves. The plain was rich with crops; there were many orchards of fruit trees and beyond the plain the mountains were brown and bare. There was fighting in the mountains and at night we could see the flashes from the artillery. In the dark it was like summer lightning, but the nights were cool and there was not the feeling of a storm coming. Sometimes in the dark we heard the troops marching under the window and guns going past pulled by motor-tractors.

train_details.author: William Blake
train_details.title: The Tyger
train_details.prediction:
Within the forge, a fiery, dreadful sight,
The Tyger burned, a creature of the night.

What hammer struck with such a fearsome hand,
To shape this beast, across the burning land?

What anvil rang with echoes dark and deep,
While shadows danced and restless spirits sleep?

A fearful symmetry, a patterned grace,
Within its eyes, a chilling, haunted space.

The flames did leap, a burning, crimson hue,
Reflecting back the terror shining through.

Did God, the Lamb, with gentle touch and mild,
Create this monster, fierce and unreconciled?

Or some dark power, in a furnace vast,
Forged this wild beast, destined to forever last?

The burning bright, a testament to pain,
A shadowed form, within a fiery reign.

A dread hand wrought this beauty, stark and bold,
A story whispered, never to be told.

What force conceived this creature, strong and free,
A paradox of wild intensity?

The anvil’s clang, a mournful, echoing plea,
“Who made thee, Tyger? Tell us, can’t you see?”
train_details.reference: Tyger! Tyger! burning bright In the forests of the night, What immortal hand or eye Could frame thy fearful symmetry? In what distant deeps or skies Burnt the fire of thine eyes? On what wings dare he aspire? What the hand, dare seize the fire? And what shoulder, & what art, Could twist the sinews of thy heart? And when thy heart began to beat, What dread hand? & what dread feet? What the hammer? what the chain? In what furnace was thy brain? What the anvil? what dread grasp Dare its deadly terrors clasp? When the stars threw down their spears, And water'd heaven with their tears, Did he smile his work to see? Did he who made the Lamb make thee? Tyger! Tyger! burning bright In the forests of the night, What immortal hand or eye Dare frame thy fearful symmetry?

train_details.author: Saki
train_details.title: The Open Window
train_details.prediction:
Framton Nuttel, a man whose nerves were perpetually on a precarious journey, found himself seated stiffly in the drawing-room of a singularly unremarkable house. Vera, his niece, regarded him with an expression of polite, almost amused, detachment. “You seem agitated, Uncle,” she observed, her voice a carefully constructed blend of coolness and concern. “Perhaps a nerve cure would be beneficial.”

He attempted a reassuring cough, a gesture that felt distinctly inadequate. “I’ve been feeling… unsettled,” he admitted, clutching his waistcoat. “The letters of introduction were rather vague, you know. One never quite knows what to expect in the countryside.” Vera, with a swiftness that bordered on theatrical, produced a small, exquisitely embroidered cushion. “Then, of course, you must rest,” she declared, placing it precisely upon the ottoman. “And I shall occupy myself with the embroidery.”

A sudden, insistent rapping at the door startled him. Vera, without a flicker of hesitation, rose and flung it open to reveal a breathless, rather bewildered postman. “A telegram, Mr. Nuttel,” she announced, her tone utterly devoid of inflection. “From your sister.” Framton, momentarily forgetting his anxieties, snatched the telegram and read it with a look of profound and utterly inexplicable horror. “Good heavens,” he stammered, “it’s… it’s about the fox.”
train_details.reference: "My aunt will be down presently, Mr. Nuttel," said a very self-possessed young lady of fifteen; "in the meantime you must try and put up with me." Framton Nuttel endeavoured to say the correct something which should duly flatter the niece of the moment without unduly discounting the aunt that was to come. Privately he doubted more than ever whether these formal visits on a succession of total strangers would do much towards helping the nerve cure which he was supposed to be undergoing. "I know how it will be," his sister had said when he was preparing to migrate to this rural retreat; "you will bury yourself down there and not speak to a living soul, and your nerves will be worse than ever from moping. I shall just give you letters of introduction to all the people I know there. Some of them, as far as I can remember, were quite nice." Framton wondered whether Mrs. Sappleton, the lady to whom he was presenting one of the letters of introduction, came into the nice division. "Do you know many of the people round here?" asked the niece, when she judged that they had had sufficient silent communion.

train_details.author: Langston Hughes
train_details.title: Mother to Son
train_details.feedback: Score=0.50 | Words=0 (target 90-120) | Motifs=2/3 | Overlap=0.49 | Missing motifs: tacks in it
train_details.prediction:
(Sound of shuffling feet, a sigh)

Look, son, don’t you see? This ain’t no crystal stair.
Not for me, no. It’s rough, it’s worn, you hear?
Like these steps, all busted and beat,
Full of tacks, sharp as a winter’s bite.

I’ve tripped, I’ve fallen, scraped my knees raw,
Felt the splinters digin’ deep, you know?
Each step a struggle, a weary plea,
Just to keep movin’ forward, you see.

Don’t think it’s easy, don’t you go thinkin’ it’s light,
This climb, this life, it ain’t no picnic.
It’s hard, it’s long, it’s full of pain,
But I’se still climbin’.

I’ve known sorrow, known loss, known the sting,
Of words like stones thrown in the dark.
But I kept my head up, kept my feet on the ground,
Just kept on movin’, leave your mark.

Don’t you let the darkness steal your shine,
Don’t you let the hurt hold you back.
Find your own stairs, your own way to rise,
And keep climbin’, son, keep climbin’ on track.

(A pause, a small, tired smile)

It’s a long road, but you’ll get there, I swear.
train_details.reference: Well, son, I'll tell you: Life for me ain't been no crystal stair. It's had tacks in it, And splinters, And boards torn up, And places with no carpet on the floor-- Bare. But all the time I'se been a-climbin' on, And reachin' landin's, And turnin' corners, And sometimes goin' in the dark Where there ain't been no light. So boy, don't you turn back. Don't you set down on the steps 'Cause you finds it's kinder hard. Don't you fall now-- For I'se still goin', honey, I'se still climbin', And life for me ain't been no crystal stair.

train_details.author: Ernest Hemingway
train_details.title: The Sun Also Rises
train_details.feedback: Score=0.41 | Words=0 (target 180-210) | Motifs=2/3 | Overlap=0.55 | Missing motifs: nose permanently flattened
train_details.prediction:
They called me a middleweight boxing champion once. A ridiculous notion, really. Spider Kelly, of all people, was the one who bestowed the title. A glancing blow, a flash of steel, and suddenly I was a hero. A fleeting, absurd hero. The chip, though, that’s what lingered. It wasn’t the flattened nose – though that certainly helped – it was the way the victory felt hollow. 

I remember the press, the congratulations, the polite smiles. They saw a fighter; I saw a boy desperately trying to prove something. Kelly, predictably, vanished. Disappeared into the fog of his own success, leaving me with the wreckage. The doctors said it was a minor fracture, easily repaired. They didn’t understand the architecture of the damage. 

Now, years later, I still catch my reflection. The nose is a permanent reminder, a small, brutal monument to a moment I never truly earned. It’s a quiet, insistent ache, a constant, dull throb beneath the surface of everything.
train_details.reference: Robert Cohn was once middleweight boxing champion of Princeton. Do not think that I am very much impressed by that as a boxing title, but it meant a lot to Cohn. He cared nothing for boxing, in fact he disliked it, but he learned it painfully and thoroughly to counteract the feeling of inferiority and shyness he had felt on being treated as a Jew at Princeton. There was a certain inner comfort in knowing he could knock down anybody who was snooty to him, although, being very shy and a thoroughly nice boy, he never fought except in the gym. He was Spider Kelly's star pupil. Spider Kelly taught all his young gentlemen to box like featherweights, no matter whether they weighed one hundred and five or two hundred and five pounds. But it seemed to fit Cohn. He was really very fast. He was so good that Spider promptly overmatched him and got his nose permanently flattened. This increased Cohn's distaste for boxing, but it gave him a certain satisfaction of some strange sort, and it certainly improved his nose.

val_details.author: Robert Frost
val_details.title: The Road Not Taken
val_details.prediction:
The forest breathed, a humid, shadowed hue,
Two paths diverged, a choice I had to make,
One worn and smooth, a well-trod, easy view,
While deeper still, a darker promise take,
A yellow wood, inviting, strange and new.

The beaten track, a comfort to the soul,
Led onward, safe, with certainty and grace,
Yet something whispered, taking its control,
A yearning for a wilder, lonely space,
To wander where no other foot had strolled.

I chose the path less traveled by, it’s true,
A tangled growth of brambles, sharp and deep,
With shadowed depths and mysteries anew,
Where secrets slumbered, silent and asleep,
And solitude a constant, watchful hue.

Now years have passed, a future I survey,
And ponder on the road I did embrace,
A quiet sigh escapes me, far away,
A wistful thought within my heart’s soft sway,
Perhaps the comfort was a better way.
val_details.reference: The Road Not Taken by Robert Frost Two roads diverged in a yellow wood, And sorry I could not travel both And be one traveler, long I stood And looked down one as far as I could To where it bent in the undergrowth; Then took the other, as just as fair, And having perhaps the better claim, Because it was grassy and wanted wear; Though as for that the passing there Had worn them really about the same, And both that morning equally lay In leaves no step had trodden black. Oh, I kept the first for another day! Yet knowing how way leads on to way, I doubted if I should ever come back. I shall be telling this with a sigh Somewhere ages and ages hence: Two roads diverged in a wood, and I-- I took the one less traveled by, And that has made all the difference.

val_details.author: P G Wodehouse
val_details.title: Carry On Jeeves
val_details.feedback: Score=0.41 | Words=0 (target 170-200) | Motifs=2/3 | Overlap=0.56 | Missing motifs: the man's a genius
val_details.prediction:
Honestly, Jeeves, you’re a frightfully useful chap. Absolutely indispensable, really. It’s a bit of a bother, of course, having to explain it all, but one does feel obliged. Take, for instance, the whole Easeby business. A right pickle, that was. Involved a pair of silk socks, naturally. A rather fetching shade of puce, if I recall. And a chap who wasn’t entirely sure where they’d ended up. 

It all stemmed from a rather enthusiastic attempt to impress Aunt Agatha, you see. She’s a terror, that woman. Anyway, the man – a perfectly decent sort, but undeniably a genius – had misplaced them. And, well, the trail led rather directly to his quarters. A bit of a scandal, naturally. Jeeves, of course, smoothed it all over with the sort of effortless grace only he possesses. 

It’s a wonder I haven’t been completely undone. Honestly, Jeeves, you’re a marvel. A truly remarkable fellow. One simply couldn’t manage without you, you know. Couldn’t possibly.
val_details.reference: Now, touching this business of old Jeeves--my man, you know--how do we stand? Lots of people think I'm much too dependent on him. My Aunt Agatha, in fact, has even gone so far as to call him my keeper. Well, what I say is: Why not? The man's a genius. From the collar upward he stands alone, I gave up trying to run my own affairs within a week of his coming to me. That was about half a dozen years ago, directly after the rather rummy business of Florence Craye, my Uncle Willoughby's book, and Edwin, the Boy Scout. The thing really began when I got back to Easeby, my uncle's place in Shropshire. I was spending a week or so there, as I generally did in the summer; and I had had to break my visit to come back to London to get a new valet. I had found Meadowes, the fellow I had taken to Easeby with me, sneaking my silk socks, a thing no bloke of spirit could stick at any price.

val_details.author: Mark Twain
val_details.title: The Celebrated Jumping Frog of Calaveras County
val_details.prediction:
Now, I’ve met a great many fools in my time, but Simon Wheeler takes the biscuit. He was a harmless enough sort, really, a man devoted entirely to telling stories, particularly about other people. I was just passing through an ancient mining camp, you see, looking for a bit of quiet, when he insisted on regaling me with the history of Jim Smiley. Smiley, he claimed, was the most meticulous, most aggravating, most persistent little short-tailed gambler in the West. 

He’d bet on anything – a frog’s ability to swim, a dog’s speed, a man’s ability to tell the truth. And this particular frog, he swore, was a champion. Smiley had spent a week training it, feeding it, and coaxing it to swim faster. It was a ridiculous endeavor, of course, but Wheeler insisted it was a matter of honor. He’d even wagered fifty dollars that the frog could outswim any other frog in the county. I’m telling you, it was a spectacle. A truly baffling spectacle, and I’m only just getting started.
val_details.reference: In compliance with the request of a friend of mine, who wrote me from the East, I called on good-natured, garrulous old Simon Wheeler, and inquired after my friend's friend, Leonidas W. Smiley, as requested to do, and I hereunto append the result. I have a lurking suspicion that Leonidas W. Smiley is a myth; that my friend never knew such a personage; and that he only conjectured that if I asked old Wheeler about him, it would remind him of his infamous Jim Smiley, and he would go to work and bore me to death with some infernal reminiscence of him as long and tedious as it should be useless to me. If that was the design, it succeeded. I found Simon Wheeler dozing comfortably by the bar-room stove of the old, dilapidated tavern in the ancient mining camp of Angel's. I noticed that he was fat and bald-headed, and had an expression of winning gentleness and simplicity upon his tranquil countenance. He roused up and gave me good-day. I told him that a friend of mine had commissioned me to make some inquiries about a cherished companion of his boyhood named Leonidas W.

val_details.author: Edgar Allan Poe
val_details.title: The Cask of Amontillado
val_details.feedback: Score=0.41 | Words=0 (target 200-220) | Motifs=2/3 | Overlap=0.55 | Missing motifs: connoisseurship in wine
val_details.prediction:
It is just – you perceive it is just – that I should corrected the injustice. My family had been marked by Fortunato’s envy for a thousand injuries, real and imagined. Thus, I resolved that Virago should experience a pleasure as refined as it was terrible. I took that which pleased me most, and began.

The timing was crucial, of course. A cold December evening, when Fortunato’s pride was at its most vulnerable. He, a connoisseur of wine, a man whose judgment was clouded by his passion for the grape, was easily lured. It was a masterful deception, a subtle manipulation of his vanity. I requested his assistance in examining a collection of Amontillado, knowing full well his eagerness to prove his expertise.

Punish with impunity, I declared to myself, is the first rule of a truly effective revenge. It is not enough to inflict pain; one must ensure it is delivered without consequence. Fortunato’s weakness for wine, his inflated sense of self-importance – these were the keys to unlocking his doom. Let him revel in the warmth of the cellar, let him believe he is indulging in a delightful pursuit, while I, in my shadowed domain, prepare the final, exquisite justice.
val_details.reference: The thousand injuries of Fortunato I had borne as I best could, but when he ventured upon insult I vowed revenge. You, who so well know the nature of my soul, will not suppose, however, that I gave utterance to a threat. At length I would be avenged; this was a point definitely settled--but the very definitiveness with which it was resolved precluded the idea of risk. I must not only punish but punish with impunity. A wrong is unredressed when retribution overtakes its redresser. It is equally unredressed when the avenger fails to make himself felt as such to him who has done the wrong. It must be understood that neither by word nor deed had I given Fortunato cause to doubt my good will. I continued, as was my wont, to smile in his face, and he did not perceive that my smile now was at the thought of his immolation. He had a weak point--this Fortunato--although in other regards he was a man to be respected and even feared. He prided himself on his connoisseurship in wine. Few Italians have the true virtuoso spirit. For the most part their enthusiasm is adopted to suit the time and opportunity, to practise imposture upon the British and Austrian millionaires.

val_details.author: Oscar Wilde
val_details.title: The Happy Prince
val_details.prediction:
High above the city, on a tall column of grey stone, stood the Happy Prince. He was a statue of gold, dazzling in the sunlight, and his eyes were bright sapphires that seemed to hold all the blue of the sky. Below, the townsfolk hurried about, oblivious to his silent vigil. They admired his beauty, of course, pointing and whispering, “How splendid he is!” But the Prince noticed their poverty, the ragged children, the hungry mothers, and a strange sadness began to creep into his golden heart.

He wished he could help, so he began to give away his jewels. First, he lost his ruby, which tumbled down into a dark alley. Then, his emeralds disappeared, glittering briefly before vanishing. Soon, only his sapphires remained, and as he wept for the moon, a single tear fell, shimmering like a diamond.

The people noticed, and they cried for the Prince, not for his lost jewels, but for his sorrow. They realized, with a sudden, sharp pang, that his beauty had masked a deep and aching compassion. He was, after all, a prince who cried for the moon, and for the suffering of his city.
val_details.reference: High above the city, on a tall column, stood the statue of the Happy Prince. He was gilded all over with thin leaves of fine gold, for eyes he had two bright sapphires, and a large red ruby glowed on his sword-hilt. He was very much admired indeed. "He is as beautiful as a weathercock," remarked one of the Town Councillors who wished to gain a reputation for having artistic tastes; "only not quite so useful," he added, fearing lest people should think him unpractical, which he really was not. "Why can't you be like the Happy Prince?" asked a sensible mother of her little boy who was crying for the moon. "The Happy Prince never dreams of crying for anything." "I am glad there is some one in the world who is quite happy," muttered a disappointed man as he gazed at the wonderful statue. "He looks just like an angel," said the Charity Children as they came out of the cathedral in their bright scarlet cloaks and their clean white pinafores. "How do you know?" said the Mathematical Master, "you have never seen one." "Ah! but we have, in our dreams," answered the children; and the Mathematical Master frowned and looked very severe, for he did not approve of children dreaming.

val_details.author: Kate Chopin
val_details.title: The Story of an Hour
val_details.feedback: Score=0.30 | Words=0 (target 190-210) | Motifs=1/3 | Overlap=0.52 | Missing motifs: railroad disaster, storm of grief
val_details.prediction:
Louise Mallard felt the news settle, a cold stone in her stomach. It was about the railroad, a splintered wreck miles away, and the word “disaster” clung to the air like rain. She rose, a slow, deliberate movement, and walked toward the open window. The room swam slightly, the afternoon light fractured by the sudden, sharp awareness. Outside, the sky was bruised purple, mirroring the gathering storm within her. A gust of wind rattled the panes, a frantic, insistent sound. She pressed her forehead against the cool glass, the dampness a small, unwelcome comfort.

The world beyond seemed suddenly vast, indifferent to the tragedy unfolding within her own small space. It was a world of wind and rain, of distant fields and the relentless, unknowable rhythm of the rails. A wave of grief, sharp and unexpected, crashed over her, stealing her breath. It wasn’t just the loss of lives, she realized, but the shattering of a carefully constructed reality. The open window offered no escape, only a stark reminder of the boundless, uncaring expanse of existence. She remained there, a solitary figure framed against the darkening sky, lost in the private storm of her revelation.
val_details.reference: Knowing that Mrs. Mallard was afflicted with a heart trouble, great care was taken to break to her as gently as possible the news of her husband's death. It was her sister Josephine who told her, in broken sentences; her husband's friend Richards was there, too. It was he who had been in the newspaper office when intelligence of the railroad disaster was received. He had only taken the time to assure himself of its truth by a second telegram, and had hastened to forestall any less careful, less tender friend in bearing the sad message. She did not hear the story as many women have heard the same, with a paralyzed inability to accept its significance. She wept at once, with sudden, wild abandonment, in her sister's arms. When the storm of grief had spent itself she went away to her room alone. She would have no one follow her. There stood, facing the open window, a comfortable, roomy armchair. She sank into it. She could see in the open square before her house the tops of trees that were all aquiver with the new spring life. The delicious breath of rain was in the air.

seed_instruction:
You are a meticulous literary mimic.
Follow every component of the instruction and stylistic cues.
Guidelines:
- Stay within the requested word count window.
- Mirror the narrative voice, tone, and structure implied by the context.
- Work each motif into the piece naturally; avoid simple name-dropping.
- Keep factual claims inside the provided context; never invent outside references.
- Prefer concrete sensory detail over generic statements.
- For poems, preserve line-based cadence and rhyme patterns signaled in the context.
- For prose, produce flowing paragraphs with sentence rhythms reflecting the author.
Output format (JSON only): {"answer": "...", "reflection": "Brief self-review covering word count fit, motif coverage, style/cadence adherence, and any fixes to improve."}.
optimized_instruction:
You will be given an instruction and a context related to a literary or stylistic writing task. Your goal is to generate a written passage that meets the specified word count and stylistic requirements, while incorporating given thematic motifs and narrative elements.

Specifically, you must:

1. Analyze the instruction carefully to understand the desired style, narrative perspective, tone, and word count range (usually around 180-220 words, or as specified).

2. Use the context to identify:
   - The theme and key motifs to be included.
   - The narrative voice and perspective (e.g., first-person with irony, formal elegy, omniscient narrator).
   - Stylistic fingerprints such as sentence length and structure, punctuation and formatting cues (e.g., punctuation rate, newline rate), and cadence (e.g., surprisal, rhythm).
   - The emotional or psychological states to be conveyed through character or narrator.

3. Incorporate all specified motifs and thematic elements naturally and subtly into the passage, avoiding overt exposition or heavy-handedness.

4. Maintain fidelity to the narrative perspective and style indicated, replicating authorial style and narrative techniques (e.g., Saki’s dry wit, French realism’s precise social detail, formal meter and rhyme).

5. Balance direct speech and formal narration as appropriate to the style, ensuring coherence and well-paced narrative flow.

6. Use sentence length and punctuation patterns that reflect the stylistic fingerprint of the context, mixing short and long sentences to create rhythm and tone.

7. Reflect social or psychological themes through character interaction, setting description, or internal monologue, capturing emotional nuance and subtlety.

8. Keep the word count within the target range, allowing minor flexibility only if it enhances the narrative.

9. Review the passage for stylistic consistency, thematic integration, and narrative clarity.

Additional domain-specific notes:

- Motifs are key thematic or narrative elements that must be included explicitly or implicitly in the passage (e.g., “middleweight boxing champion,” “fearful trip is done,” “fallen cold and dead”).

- Stylistic fingerprints may include quantitative measures such as punctuation rate, newline rate, surprisal density, and average sentence length; use these as guides to replicate the cadence and tone of the exemplar context.

- The tone may require subtle irony, understatement, social satire, or formal mourning; adapt your language and narrative voice accordingly.

- When writing character sketches or first-person narratives, aim for a voice that is cool, appraising, or emotionally nuanced, using internal monologue and indirect commentary rather than explicit statements.

- For formal poetic forms (e.g., elegies), adhere to the specified stanza and line structure, rhyme scheme, and meter, balancing thematic contrasts (e.g., triumph and grief) through refrains or repeated motifs.

- The passage should feel authentic to the requested style and theme, blending literary analysis with creative writing.

In summary, your output should be a stylistically faithful, thematically rich, and well-crafted literary passage that meets the detailed instructions and context provided, including motifs, tone, narrative perspective, and word count, while reflecting the stylistic fingerprints and narrative nuances of the exemplar context.
